   Ms. [**Known lastname 8562**] is a 74 year old female with past medical history of
   metastatic breast cancer, DVT on coumadin, prior CVA and
   cardiomyopathy, who presents with altered mental status.
   .
   #.  Altered Mental Status, weakness: Ddx  includes infection (likely
   LLL infiltrate), hypocalcemia, leptomeningeal spread of breast CA,
   hypoperfusion, toxic/metabolic encephalopathy (pt was in renal
   failure), narcotics, seizure secondary to brain mets.  Could be
   contributing to exacerbation of  old CVA deficits.
   -CT of the head negtive for CVA or TIA, bleed, or new edema.
   Plan:
   - Will hold antibiotics for bacterial meningitis (already received
   vancomycin, ceftriaxone, and ampicillin), given no true signs of
   meningmus on exam, no fevers, and history no really consistent with
   this, after further discussion with husband as noted above.
   - Follow up culture data (blood, sputum if possible, urine)
   - Follow up electrolytes in setting of acute renal failure
   - Follow up final head CT read, consider repeat imaging in next day or
   days to assess for evolving process.
   - Support blood pressure as needed with IVF and pressors if needed for
   MAP >55-60
   - No LP given elevated INR, thrombocytopenia, husband
s wishes for no
   invasive procedures
   - Renal failure management as discussed below
   - Continue lactulose for question of hepatic encephalopathy (waiting
   for LFTs to return, has history of liver involvement of metastases)
   - Touch base with Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 810**] or covering neuro oncologist
   - transfuse another unit pRBCs to HCT >30
   .
   #. Acute renal failure: Given elevated BUN, could be all pre-renal in
   setting of poor PO intake reported by family and continuation of home
   BP medications (ACE-I, lasix, and Coreg). Her baseline creatinine is
   0.5. Given lack of urination, post-obstructive etiology is also a
   possibility although she has no known metastates in the pelvis that
   would account for obstruction..
   - FeNa 0.1%, Una 12, Uosm 329
   - Will consider checking renal ultrasound in AM if not improving after
   hydration
   - No schistocytes on multiple smears to suspect TTPHUS
   - Urine eos neg
   - bolus fluid/blood prn UOP
   .
   #. Hypotension: Per hematology/oncology clinic notes, patient's
   baseline blood pressure over the last several weeks was recorded as
   80-90/50. It has improved after receiving three liters of IVF to
   systolic currently 100-130's. No reason to be adrenal metastases known,
   but will consider [**Last Name (un) 45**] stim should she remain hypotensive. Does not
   appear to be sepsis but checking cultures. Also may have low baseline
   in setting of cardiomyopathy. In the ICU has gotten 1U pRBCs and 50cc
   D5HCO3 for low urine output with BPs in 80s-90s.
   - Continue D5 bicarb/blood boluses as needed for low urine output or
   systolic <85, or if symptomatic. EF most recently 50% and satting 100%
   allowing for aggressive fluid resuscitation.
   - Should she develop signs of fluid overload, will need to initiate
   pressor support
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Platelets 68 on presentation. She is day 18 of her
   gemcitabine therapy, so this could represent marrow suppression from
   that cycle (WBC could be disporportionally up secondary to
   administration of GSC-F). Consistent with severity and timing of prior
   post chemo thrombocytopenia.
   - Holding anti-platelet agents in setting of low count, no SQ heparin.
   - Monitor for signs of bleeding, transfuse should count be <20K or have
   symptoms
   .
   #. Anemia: Patient's last HCT was 29, with values since [**Month (only) 1088**] in
   29-33 range. Today presentation HCT was 23.5, which is likely
   hemoconcentrated. Suspect large part of this may be marrow suppression
   secondary to chemotherapy, as has no signs of bleeding (guaiac negative
   in ED).
   - Hemolysis labs neg
   - poor reticulocytosis and anemia of chronic disease to account for
   macrocytosis and microcytosis respectively.
   - Iron, B12 and folate all nondeficient
   - s/p transfusion of 1U with appropriate [**Last Name (LF) 7676**], [**First Name3 (LF) 178**] repeat today to
   goal 30
   .
   #. Pruritis: Per husband, and as noted on skin examination, this has
   been a major complaint over the last week. Most likely effect of
   oxycodone (timing consistent and common). Less likely uremia as
   pruritis persists after improved renal function, and bilirubin normal.
   TSH and ferritin also normal.
   - Sarna and benadryl prn (taken without worsened MS)
   .
   #. Bilateral leg pain: Likely due to compression by known spinal mets.
   No sign of cord compresion or cauda equina as rectal tone and sensation
   in tact.
   - Unclear use of imaging given no plan for procedures.
   - Symptomatic treatment with morphine IV prn, avoid oxycodone due to
   pruritis
   - Will consider LENI for DVT in AM once stable (already therapeutic on
   coumadin though, and swelling is more on leg affected by stroke)
   .
   #. Breast Cancer: Per discussion with husband, further treatment will
   be with different [**Doctor Last Name **], however at this time, no active treatment
   while inpatient.
   - Will further discuss management with primary oncology team in the AM
   .
   #. Failure to thrive: Per OMR notes and discussion with husband, she
   has lost a significant amount of weight (>20 pounds) over the last
   several months, and has very poor PO intake. A trial of megace had been
   initiated, however this was stopped due to interaction with her
   coumadin and supratherapeutic INR.
   - Nutrition consult placed, NPO for now
   - Will need to further discuss this with husband and primary oncology

   .
   #. History of DVT: Patient's INR is supratherapeutic. No current signs

   of vitamin K in diet may be contributing to elevated INR.
   Administration of antibiotics may further increase INR.

   #. History of cardiomyopathy: Holding ACE-I, lasix, and coreg in

   depressed EF, however appears hypovolemic at present.
   .

Summary:

Ms. [**Known lastname 8562**], a 74-year-old female with a past medical history of metastatic breast cancer, DVT on coumadin, prior CVA, and cardiomyopathy, presents with altered mental status, weakness, and hypotension. She has been experiencing pruritis, bilateral leg pain, and failure to thrive. Her laboratory results show thrombocytopenia, anemia, and acute renal failure. She is currently receiving IVF and antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: Given the patient's altered mental status, weakness, and hypotension, infection is a potential complication. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, which may indicate an infection.
2. Hypocalcemia: The patient's laboratory results show low calcium levels, which can cause altered mental status, weakness, and hypotension.
3. Leptomeningeal spread of breast cancer: The patient's past medical history of metastatic breast cancer and her current symptoms of altered mental status and weakness may indicate leptomeningeal spread of breast cancer.
4. Hypoperfusion: The patient's hypotension and altered mental status may indicate hypoperfusion, which can cause organ dysfunction.
5. Toxic/metabolic encephalopathy: The patient's altered mental status and weakness may be caused by toxic or metabolic encephalopathy, which can be caused by a variety of factors, including medications, electrolyte imbalances, and organ dysfunction.
6. Seizure secondary to brain mets: The patient's past medical history of brain metastases and her current symptoms of altered mental status and weakness may indicate seizure activity.
7. Acute renal failure: The patient's laboratory results show elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels, which may indicate acute renal failure.
8. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's laboratory results show low platelet count, which can cause bleeding complications.
9. Anemia: The patient's laboratory results show low hemoglobin and hematocrit levels, which can cause fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
10. Pruritis: The patient's symptoms of pruritis may be caused by a variety of factors, including allergic reactions, medication side effects, and skin conditions.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's altered mental status, weakness, and hypotension require immediate attention. The patient's laboratory results show evidence of infection, hypocalcemia, and acute renal failure, which need to be treated promptly. The patient's thrombocytopenia and anemia require careful monitoring and treatment. The patient's pruritis may require treatment with antihistamines or corticosteroids.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Holding antibiotics for bacterial meningitis until further evaluation and testing.
2. Following up on culture data and laboratory results.
3. Monitoring the patient's electrolytes and renal function.
4. Providing supportive care, including IVF and antibiotics.
5. Considering repeat imaging to assess for evolving processes.
6. Holding anti-platelet agents and monitoring for signs of bleeding.
7. Transfusing blood products as necessary.
8. Providing pain management with oxycodone and tylenol.
9. Consulting with a nutritionist and considering a trial of megace.
10. Discussing management with the primary oncology team.

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and her husband has expressed a desire to avoid invasive procedures unless they would have a palliative effect.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a history of widely metastatic malignancy and multiple medical complications. The patient has experienced tachycardia, which responded to iv beta-blocker, and has been experiencing disorientation and confusion. The patient's mental status is altered, with concerns for toxic/metabolic response to pneumonia, hypocalcemia, CNS infection, leptomeningeal involvement of tumor, increased/progression of CNS tumor, encephalitis, and medication effect.

The patient has a mild case of hypocalcemia, which needs to be corrected. The patient also has pruritus, which is being treated symptomatically. The patient is experiencing agitation, which may be related to the underlying process. The patient has acute renal failure, which is resolving with iv fluids.

The patient has an indwelling iv catheter, which may be causing a line-related infection. Empirical antimicrobials have been started. The patient has a history of DVT and is being monitored for PT on coumadin. The patient's nutritional support is being withheld due to NPO status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's altered mental status and pruritus may be indicative of sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory support is critical, and any deterioration in oxygenation or ventilation could lead to respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrest: The patient's tachycardia and altered mental status may increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic renal failure if not managed properly.
5. Infection: The patient's indwelling iv catheter and history of DVT increase the risk of line-related infection and DVT, respectively.
6. CNS complications: The patient's altered mental status and history of CNS tumor increase the risk of CNS complications, such as seizures, stroke, and meningitis.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's NPO status and history of malignancy increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, and bowel obstruction.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a history of malignancy and extensive metastasis. They are currently admitted to the ICU for management of their condition. The patient has experienced tachycardia, which responded to iv beta-blocker, and has shown signs of disorientation and confusion. They have also experienced hypovolemia, which has improved with fluid replacement. The patient's mental status has been assessed as altered, with concerns about toxic or metabolic responses to pneumonia, hypocalcemia, CNS infection, or medication effects.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient's indwelling iv catheter may be a source of line-related infection, and empirical antimicrobials have been started.
2. Renal Failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which is resolving with iv fluids, but needs to be closely monitored.
3. Hypocalcemia: The patient has mild hypocalcemia, which needs to be corrected, and ionized calcium levels should be checked.
4. Pruritis: The patient is experiencing pruritis, which is being managed with symptomatic treatment and trial prn atarax.
5. Agitation: The patient's agitation is possible related to the underlying process and needs to be closely monitored.
6. Malignancy: The patient's extensive and widely metastatic malignancy needs to be managed accordingly.
7. DVT: The patient has a history of DVT and is on coumadin, which needs to be monitored, and may need to be held while considering LP.
8. NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT: The patient is NPO, and their nutritional needs need to be assessed and addressed.
9. ICU Care: The patient requires close monitoring and management in the ICU, including prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.
2. Continue to manage the patient's hypovolemia with fluid replacement and monitor for signs of fluid overload.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and adjust treatment accordingly.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hypocalcemia and pruritis.
5. Consider LP to assess for infection or malignancy.
6. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. Monitor the patient's DVT and adjust treatment accordingly.
8. Assess and address the patient's nutritional needs.
9. Continue to provide ICU care, including prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

   Assessment and Plan
   Ms. [**Known lastname 8562**] is a 74 year old female with past medical history of
   metastatic breast cancer, DVT on coumadin, prior CVA and
   cardiomyopathy, who presents with altered mental status.
   .
   #.  Altered Mental Status, weakness: Ddx  includes infection (likely
   LLL infiltrate), hypocalcemia, leptomeningeal spread of breast CA,
   hypoperfusion, toxic/metabolic encephalopathy (pt was in renal
   failure), narcotics, seizure secondary to brain mets.  Could be
   contributing to exacerbation of  old CVA deficits.
   -CT of the head negtive for CVA or TIA, bleed, or new edema.  Pt still
   has innumerable calcified metastatic foci and mild edema.
   Plan:
   -Hypocalcemia: repleated Ca2+
   - Will discuss with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 810**] the possibility of leptomeningeal dz and
   whether LP and cytology would help.  Unable to get MRI given pt has
   severe clostrophobia.  Holding ibuprofen and coumadin given possibility
   of LP.
   -Bacterial meningitis in ddx but no meningeal sign/fever: pt already on
   ceftriaxone and vancomycin for PNA.  If concern for meningitis
   increases would start ampicillin.
   -Infection: LLL infiltrate likely.  Continue ceftriaxone and vanco.
   f/u blood cx still pending, urine cx negative
   -Goal MAP >55-60
   - Continue lactulose for question of hepatic encephalopathy
   -Haldol prn for agitation
   -Avoid narcotics and benadryl as much as possible
   .
   #. Acute renal failure:  Given elevated BUN, could be all pre-renal
   (fena 0.1%) in setting of poor PO intake reported by family and
   continuation of home BP medications (ACE-I, lasix, and Coreg). Her
   baseline creatinine is 0.5.  Trend of creatinine 2.3 -> 1.9 -> 1.7 ->
   0.8.
   -continue to trend creatinine
   .
   #PNA: continue cetriaxone and vancomycin.
   .
   #. Hypotension: Per hematology/oncology clinic notes, patient's
   baseline blood pressure over the last several weeks was recorded as
   80-90/50.  Today  pt normotensive (required fluid bolus earlier in
   admission).
   .
   #Increased LFTs
   -RUQ u/s today
   -follow LFTs
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Platelets 68 on presentation. She is day 19 of her
   gemcitabine therapy, so this could represent marrow suppression from
   that cycle (WBC could be disporportionally up secondary to
   administration of GSC-F). Consistent with severity and timing of prior
   post chemo thrombocytopenia.
   - Holding anti-platelet agents in setting of low count, no SQ heparin.
   - Monitor for signs of bleeding, transfuse should count be <20K or have
   symptoms
   .
   #. Anemia: HCT since [**Month (only) 1088**] in 29-33 range. On presentation HCT was
   23.5 and now is 32. Suspect large part of this may be marrow
   suppression secondary to chemotherapy, as has no signs of bleeding
   (guaiac negative in ED).  s/p transfusion of 1U with appropriate bump.
   - Hemolysis labs neg
   - poor reticulocytosis and anemia of chronic disease to account for
   macrocytosis and microcytosis respectively.
   - Iron, B12 and folate all nondeficient
   -.
   #. Pruritis: Per husband, and as noted on skin examination, this has
   been a major complaint over the last week. Most likely effect of
   oxycodone (timing consistent and common). Less likely uremia as
   pruritis persists after improved renal function, and bilirubin normal.
   TSH and ferritin also normal.
   - Sarna and atorax prn.
   .
   #. Bilateral leg pain: Likely due to compression by known spinal mets.
   No sign of cord compresion or cauda equina as rectal tone and sensation
   in tact.
   - Unclear use of imaging given no plan for procedures.
   - Symptomatic treatment with low doses of tylenol or ibuprofen.
   .
   #SVT:
   -metoprolol 5mg IV Prn for HR >120
   .
   #. Breast Cancer: Per discussion with husband, further treatment will
   be with different [**Doctor Last Name **], however at this time, no active treatment
   while inpatient.
   - Will further discuss management with primary oncology team in the AM
   .
   #. Failure to thrive: Per OMR notes and discussion with husband, she
   has lost a significant amount of weight (>20 pounds) over the last
   several months, and has very poor PO intake. A trial of megace had been
   initiated, however this was stopped due to interaction with her
   coumadin and supratherapeutic INR.
   - Nutrition consult placed, NPO for now
   .
   #. History of DVT: Patient's INR was supratherapeutic and now
   subtherapeutic. No current signs of bleeding or history of bleeding.
   - Holding coumadin given possibility of LP, type and cross sent in
   event she needs to be urgently reversed.
   .
   #. History of cardiomyopathy: Holding ACE-I, lasix, and coreg in
   setting of hypotension. Will carefully monitor IVF intake given
   depressed EF, however appears hypovolemic at present.
   .
   #. FEN: IVF, D5NAHCO3 maintenance while NPO
   .
   #. Pain management with low doses of tylenol (given LFTs) and low doses
   ibuprofen (given kidney fx).

   Assessment and Plan
   Ms. [**Known lastname 8562**] is a 74 year old female with past medical history of
   metastatic breast cancer, DVT on coumadin, prior CVA and
   cardiomyopathy, who presents with altered mental status.
   .
   #.  Altered Mental Status, weakness: Ddx  includes infection (likely
   LLL infiltrate), hypocalcemia, leptomeningeal spread of breast CA,
   hypoperfusion, toxic/metabolic encephalopathy (pt was in renal
   failure), narcotics, seizure secondary to brain mets.  Could be
   contributing to exacerbation of  old CVA deficits.
   -CT of the head negtive for CVA or TIA, bleed, or new edema.  Pt still
   has innumerable calcified metastatic foci and mild edema.
   Plan:
   -Hypocalcemia: repleated Ca2+
   - Will discuss with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 810**] the possibility of leptomeningeal dz and
   whether LP and cytology would help.  Unable to get MRI given pt has
   severe clostrophobia.  Holding ibuprofen and coumadin given possibility
   of LP.
   -Bacterial meningitis in ddx but no meningeal sign/fever: pt already on
   ceftriaxone and vancomycin for PNA.  If concern for meningitis
   increases would start ampicillin.
   -Infection: LLL infiltrate likely.  Continue ceftriaxone and vanco.
   f/u blood cx still pending, urine cx negative
   -Goal MAP >55-60
   - Continue lactulose for question of hepatic encephalopathy
   -Haldol prn for agitation
   -Avoid narcotics and benadryl as much as possible
   .
   #. Acute renal failure:  Given elevated BUN, could be all pre-renal
   (fena 0.1%) in setting of poor PO intake reported by family and
   continuation of home BP medications (ACE-I, lasix, and Coreg). Her
   baseline creatinine is 0.5.  Trend of creatinine 2.3 -> 1.9 -> 1.7 ->
   0.8.
   -continue to trend creatinine
   .
   #PNA: continue cetriaxone and vancomycin.
   .
   #. Hypotension: Per hematology/oncology clinic notes, patient's
   baseline blood pressure over the last several weeks was recorded as
   80-90/50.  Today  pt normotensive (required fluid bolus earlier in
   admission).
   .
   #Increased LFTs
   -RUQ u/s today
   -follow LFTs
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Platelets 68 on presentation. She is day 19 of her
   gemcitabine therapy, so this could represent marrow suppression from
   that cycle (WBC could be disporportionally up secondary to
   administration of GSC-F). Consistent with severity and timing of prior
   post chemo thrombocytopenia.
   - Holding anti-platelet agents in setting of low count, no SQ heparin.
   - Monitor for signs of bleeding, transfuse should count be <20K or have
   symptoms
   .
   #. Anemia: HCT since [**Month (only) 1088**] in 29-33 range. On presentation HCT was
   23.5 and now is 32. Suspect large part of this may be marrow
   suppression secondary to chemotherapy, as has no signs of bleeding
   (guaiac negative in ED).  s/p transfusion of 1U with appropriate bump.
   - Hemolysis labs neg
   - poor reticulocytosis and anemia of chronic disease to account for
   macrocytosis and microcytosis respectively.
   - Iron, B12 and folate all nondeficient
   -.
   #. Pruritis: Per husband, and as noted on skin examination, this has
   been a major complaint over the last week. Most likely effect of
   oxycodone (timing consistent and common). Less likely uremia as
   pruritis persists after improved renal function, and bilirubin normal.
   TSH and ferritin also normal.
   - Sarna and atorax prn.
   .
   #. Bilateral leg pain: Likely due to compression by known spinal mets.
   No sign of cord compresion or cauda equina as rectal tone and sensation
   in tact.
   - Unclear use of imaging given no plan for procedures.
   - Symptomatic treatment with low doses of tylenol or ibuprofen.
   .
   #SVT:
   -metoprolol 5mg IV Prn for HR >120
   .
   #. Breast Cancer: Per discussion with husband, further treatment will
   be with different [**Doctor Last Name **], however at this time, no active treatment
   while inpatient.
   - Will further discuss management with primary oncology team in the AM
   .
   #. Failure to thrive: Per OMR notes and discussion with husband, she
   has lost a significant amount of weight (>20 pounds) over the last
   several months, and has very poor PO intake. A trial of megace had been
   initiated, however this was stopped due to interaction with her
   coumadin and supratherapeutic INR.
   - Nutrition consult placed, NPO for now
   .
   #. History of DVT: Patient's INR was supratherapeutic and now
   subtherapeutic. No current signs of bleeding or history of bleeding.
   - Holding coumadin given possibility of LP, type and cross sent in
   event she needs to be urgently reversed.
   .
   #. History of cardiomyopathy: Holding ACE-I, lasix, and coreg in
   setting of hypotension. Will carefully monitor IVF intake given
   depressed EF, however appears hypovolemic at present.
   .
   #. FEN: IVF, D5NAHCO3 maintenance while NPO
   .
   #. Pain management with low doses of tylenol (given LFTs) and low doses
   ibuprofen (given kidney fx).
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

**Current Condition:**

* Altered mental status
* Weakness
* Hypocalcemia (repleted)
* Potential leptomeningeal disease (under discussion with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 810**])
* Infection (likely LLL infiltrate)
* Acute renal failure (treated with IVF and monitoring)
* PNA (treated with ceftriaxone and vancomycin)
* Thrombocytopenia (platelets 68, holding anti-platelet agents)
* Anemia (HCT 32, suspected marrow suppression secondary to chemotherapy)
* Pruritis (likely due to oxycodone)
* Bilateral leg pain (likely due to compression by known spinal mets)
* SVT (treated with metoprolol 5mg IV Prn)
* Breast cancer (under management with different [**Doctor Last Name **])
* Failure to thrive (nutrition consult placed, NPO for now)
* History of DVT (INR supratherapeutic and now subtherapeutic, holding coumadin)
* History of cardiomyopathy (holding ACE-I, lasix, and coreg in setting of hypotension)

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Seizure secondary to brain mets
* Exacerbation of old CVA deficits
* Meningitis (bacterial or viral)
* Hepatic encephalopathy (given elevated LFTs and lactulose treatment)
* Hemorrhage (given thrombocytopenia and holding anti-platelet agents)
* Bleeding (given history of DVT and holding coumadin)
* Renal failure (given elevated BUN and creatinine)
* Infection (given PNA and LLL infiltrate)
* Leptomeningeal disease (given altered mental status and potential for LP)
* Cardiac complications (given history of cardiomyopathy and holding ACE-I, lasix, and coreg)

**Plan:**

* Continue monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies
* Continue treatment of hypocalcemia, infection, and PNA
* Monitor for signs of bleeding and transfuse as necessary
* Hold anti-platelet agents and coumadin until further discussion with Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 810**]
* Continue lactulose treatment for potential hepatic encephalopathy
* Avoid narcotics and benadryl as much as possible
* Continue to trend creatinine and monitor for signs of renal failure
* Consider further imaging studies (e.g., MRI) to evaluate for leptomeningeal disease
* Discuss management with primary oncology team and consider further treatment for breast cancer

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
   Ms. [**Known lastname 8562**] is a 74 year old female with past medical history of
   metastatic breast cancer, DVT on coumadin, prior CVA and
   cardiomyopathy, who presents with altered mental status and feeling of
   weakness on left side.  Has weakness on right side at baseline.
   .
   #.  Altered Mental Status: Pt had AMS on admission and thru [**2145-3-22**],
   oriented only to self and was combative.  On [**2145-3-23**] her mental status
   improved dramatically.  Thought likely to be toxic/metabolic factors in
   the setting of old CVA deficits. The toxic/metabolic factors could
   include PNA, oxycodone use, and possible small contribution of
   hypocalcemia.  There was concern for leptomeningeal disease given her
   metastatic breast cancer to the cerebellum, however, LP was not
   persueed given pt's mental status cleared and we would not expect it to
   resolve spontaneously.  Seizure could also be responsible if AMS was
   secondary to seizure. CT of the head was negtive for CVA or TIA, bleed,
   or new edema.  Pt still has innumerable calcified metastatic foci and
   mild edema.  She refused MRI given her severe clostrophobia.  Her
   oxycodone was discontinued and her calcium was repleated.  Pt did
   receive antibiotics for bacterial meningitis in the ED but they were
   not continued given that she had no fever or signs of meningismus.
   -d/c lactulose (was given for concern for hepatic encephalopathy )
   -avoid narcotics, low dose inbuprofen and Tylenol for pain.
   .
   #. PNA: Left retrocardiac mild PNA.
   -continue ceftriaxone and vanco.
   -f/u final on blood cx still pending
   .
   # Increased LFTs: RUQ was done for concern of rising LFTs given pt has
   liver mets.
   -Some biliary sludge found on RUQ ultrasound.
   .
   #. Acute renal failure:  Pt was pre-renal (FENA 0.1%) in setting of
   poor PO intake reported by family and continuation of home BP
   medications (ACE-I, lasix, and Coreg). Her baseline creatinine is 0.5.
   Her creatinine on admission was 2.3. Pt had received fluid boluses
   early on in the admission for hypotension.
   -creatinine today at 0.6
   .
   #. Hypotension: Pt was hypotensive on admission to 67 SBP and she
   received fluid boluses. Per hematology/oncology clinic notes, patient's
   baseline blood pressure over the last several weeks was recorded as
   80-90/50.
   -consider restarting BP meds tomorrow.
   .
   #. Thrombocytopenia: Platelets 68 on presentation. She was day 18 of
   her gemcitabine therapy so this liekly represent marrow suppression
   from that cycle. (WBC could be disporportionally up secondary to
   administration of GSC-F). Consistent with severity and timing of prior
   post chemo thrombocytopenia. Her coumadin was held. Her
   thrombocytonpenia improved to the 130s today.
   -continue to follow daily plts
   .
   #. Anemia: HCT since [**Month (only) 1088**] in 29-33 range. On presentation HCT was
   23.5 and now is 32. Suspect large part of this may be marrow
   suppression secondary to chemotherapy, as has no signs of bleeding
   (guaiac negative in ED).  Her hemolysis labs were negative.  Poor
   reticulocytosis and anemia of chronic disease to account for
   macrocytosis and microcytosis respectively. She received one unit of
   blood while in the ICU and bumped appropriately.  HCT stable at 28.8 on
   [**2145-3-23**].
   -daily HCT check
   .
   #. Pruritis: Per husband, and as noted on skin examination, this has
   been a major complaint over the last week prior to admission. Most
   likely secondary to oxycodone.  She was treated with benedryl which was
   later discontinued due to her MS changes.
   -consider atarax prn puritis
   #. Bilateral leg pain: Likely due to compression by known spinal mets.
   She had no signs of cord compresion or cauda equina as rectal tone and
   sensation in tact. She was pain free on day of call out from ICU.
   -ibuprofen (low dose) or tylenol (low dose given liver fx) for pain
   control.
   .
   #SVT: Pt had 2 episodes of SVT while in the ICU with HR up to 150 which
   responded to metoprolol 5IV. No episodes of SVT on [**2145-3-23**].
   .
   # Breast Cancer: Not active pt while an in patient.
   -tx plan per primary oncologist
   .
   #. Failure to thrive: Per OMR notes and discussion with husband, she
   has lost a significant amount of weight (>20 pounds) over the last
   several months, and has very poor PO intake. A trial of megace had been
   initiated, however this was stopped due to interaction with her
   coumadin and supratherapeutic INR. She was seen by nutrition and
   originally placed on a restriceted diet.
   -advanced diet to soft dysphagia
   -continue supplement with boost/ensure.
   .
   #. History of DVT: Patient's INR was supratherapeutic on admission.
   She had no signs of bleeding.  Anticoagulation was held in anticipation
   of LP. Coumadin restarted on [**2145-3-23**] at 3mg daily down from home dose
   of 5mg daily given that she was supratherapeutic and also on
   antibiotics.
   .
   #. History of cardiomyopathy: Held ACE-I, lasix, and coreg in setting
   of hypotension.
   -consider restarting tomorrow.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: soft dysphagia
   Glycemic Control:

   blood while in the ICU and bumped appropriately.  HCT stable at 28.8 on
   [**2145-3-23**].
   -daily HCT check
   .
   #. Pruritis: Per husband, and as noted on skin examination, this has
   been a major complaint over the last week prior to admission. Most
   likely secondary to oxycodone.  She was treated with benedryl which was
   later discontinued due to her MS changes.
   -consider atarax prn puritis
   #. Bilateral leg pain: Likely due to compression by known spinal mets.
   She had no signs of cord compresion or cauda equina as rectal tone and
   sensation in tact. She was pain free on day of call out from ICU.
   -ibuprofen (low dose) or tylenol (low dose given liver fx) for pain
   control.
   .
   #SVT: Pt had 2 episodes of SVT while in the ICU with HR up to 150 which
   responded to metoprolol 5IV. No episodes of SVT on [**2145-3-23**].
   .
   # Breast Cancer: Not active pt while an in patient.
   -tx plan per primary oncologist
   .
   #. Failure to thrive: Per OMR notes and discussion with husband, she
   has lost a significant amount of weight (>20 pounds) over the last
   several months, and has very poor PO intake. A trial of megace had been
   initiated, however this was stopped due to interaction with her
   coumadin and supratherapeutic INR. She was seen by nutrition and
   originally placed on a restriceted diet.
   -advanced diet to soft dysphagia
   -continue supplement with boost/ensure.
   .
   #. History of DVT: Patient's INR was supratherapeutic on admission.
   She had no signs of bleeding.  Anticoagulation was held in anticipation
   of LP. Coumadin restarted on [**2145-3-23**] at 3mg daily down from home dose
   of 5mg daily given that she was supratherapeutic and also on
   antibiotics.
   .
   #. History of cardiomyopathy: Held ACE-I, lasix, and coreg in setting
   of hypotension.
   -consider restarting tomorrow.

7. Cardiac failure: The patient's history of cardiomyopathy and low blood pressure may indicate cardiac failure.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes, which may indicate gastrointestinal bleeding.

10. Metastatic disease progression: The patient's laboratory results show elevated liver enzymes and calcium levels, which may indicate metastatic disease progression.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with a history of cancer, who is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to altered mental status, delirium, and confusion. The patient's condition is attributed to toxic-metabolic dysfunction in the setting of infection/sepsis, with possible contributions from medication effects (Levofloxacin and narcotics) and a prior cerebrovascular accident (CVA). The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 89 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 107/46 mmHg. The patient is receiving IV fluids, antibiotics, and pain management medications.

The patient's laboratory results show mild hypocalcemia, with an ionized calcium level of 0.6 mg/dL. The patient's white blood cell count is 4.5-5.8 x 10^9/L, and their platelet count is 68-130 x 10^9/L. The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 58 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 32 IU/L.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Continued ICU care with close monitoring of vital signs and laboratory results.
2. Administration of IV fluids to manage hypovolemia.
3. Management of hypocalcemia with calcium supplementation.
4. Antibiotic therapy for possible line-related infection.
5. Pain management with narcotics.
6. Resumption of PO nutrition under supervision.
7. Consideration of formal speech and swallow evaluation if concerns arise.

Potential medical complications:

1. Infection/sepsis: The patient's altered mental status and delirium may be attributed to toxic-metabolic dysfunction in the setting of infection/sepsis.
2. Hypocalcemia: The patient's mild hypocalcemia may require close monitoring and calcium supplementation to prevent complications.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may require continued IV fluids and close monitoring of kidney function.
4. Malignancy: The patient's extensive and widely metastatic cancer may require ongoing management and treatment.
5. Line-related infection: The patient's indwelling IV catheter may be at risk for line-related infection, which requires empirical antimicrobial therapy.
6. DVT: The patient's history of DVT may require continued anticoagulation therapy with coumadin.
7. Nutritional support: The patient's nutritional support may require close monitoring and adjustment to prevent complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient's condition is as follows:

The patient's mental status has improved, with reduced agitation and beligerance. They are now cooperative and oriented. However, they still have altered mental status, delirium, and confusion, which is attributed to toxic-metabolic dysfunction in the setting of infection/sepsis, with possible contribution of medication effect (Levofloxacin and narcotics) on the background of prior CVA.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C (99.8°F), heart rate of 89 bpm, blood pressure of 107/46 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute. They are receiving oxygen therapy and have a SpO2 of 96%.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, and they are overweight/obese. They have a normal-sized head, normal pupillary reflexes, and normal breath sounds. They are able to follow simple commands and respond to verbal stimuli.

Laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 9.6 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 4.5-5.8 K/uL
* Platelet count: 68-130 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.6-1.9 mg/dL
* Glucose: 77-103 mg/dL
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 15.8/27.3/1.4, ALT/AST: 32/58, Alk Phos/T Bili: 103/0.9, Differential-Neuts: 77.0%, Band: 0.0%, Lymph: 5.0%, Mono: 15.0%, Eos: 2.0%, Fibrinogen: 373 mg/dL, Lactic Acid: 0.8 mmol/L, Albumin: 2.2 g/dL, LDH: 411 IU/L, Ca++: 8.2 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 2.8 mg/dL

The patient's plan includes:

* Altered mental status, delirium, and confusion: continue to monitor and manage as needed.
* Hypovolemia: continue to monitor and manage as needed.
* Hypocalcemia: check ionized calcium and replete as needed.
* Pruritis: symptomatic treatment.
* Agitation: resolved.
* Renal failure: continue to monitor and manage as needed.
* Malignancy: continue to manage as needed.
* Possible infection: consider empirical antimicrobials.
* h/o DVT: resume coumadin and monitor PT on coumadin.
* Nutritional support: resume PO under supervision and consider formal speech/swallow evaluation if concern.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Infection/sepsis
* Malignancy progression
* Renal failure
* Electrolyte imbalance (hypocalcemia)
* Pruritis
* Agitation
* DVT

It is essential to continue to monitor the patient's condition and adjust their plan as needed to prevent or manage these potential complications.
